message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest that the patient has a congenital heart defect, likely patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a prostaglandin synthetase inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in closing a PDA in a preterm neonate. Therefore, it is the next step in treatment of this patient. Antibiotics and PGE2 are not indicated in this scenario, and a heart transplant would not be considered at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated heart rate, widened pulse pressure, difficulty breathing, and harsh, machine-like murmur suggest a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a drug used to close a PDA. Antibiotics and PGE2 are not relevant in this case. A heart transplant is not typically considered for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with signs and symptoms of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is verified by echocardiogram. Indomethacin is used to close a PDA in infants. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is evidence of infection. PGE2 is used to keep PDA open in certain cases, but not in this situation. Heart transplant is not indicated unless patient has end stage heart failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated heart rate, widened pulse pressure, and machine-like murmur suggest a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is given in order to close the PDA. Antibiotics may be given to treat infection, but there is no indication of infection in this case. PGE2 is given in order to keep the ductus open in some cases, but that is not appropriate in this situation. A heart transplant may be considered in severe cases, but it is not the next step in treatment for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest the patient has a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is used to close a PDA in neonates. Antibiotics are not needed for this condition. PGE2 is used to keep a PDA open in patients with certain heart defects. A heart transplant is not needed in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest the diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a medication commonly used for PDA closure in neonates. Antibiotics would not be indicated unless there is evidence of infection. PGE2 would actually promote the shunting of blood through the PDA. Heart transplant would not be indicated at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and significant cardiac murmur indicate a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a common congenital heart defect in Down syndrome patients. Indomethacin is a first line treatment to close the PDA. Antibiotics are not indicated, PGE2 is used to maintain patency of the ductus arteriosus, and heart transplant is not recommended for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated heart rate, widened pulse pressure, and machine-like murmur suggests a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is used to close the PDA and is the appropriate initial treatment for this patient. Antibiotics may be used if there is evidence of infection, but they are not indicated in this case. PGE2 is used to maintain PDA in patients with certain congenital heart defects. Heart transplantation is not indicated for PDA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest that the patient has a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which can be confirmed with echocardiogram. Indomethacin is the initial treatment for PDA closure in infants. Antibiotics would not be indicated unless there is an infection. PGE2 would be used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in certain congenital heart defects. A heart transplant is not indicated at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated heart rate, widened pulse pressure, and difficulty breathing indicate a heart problem, and the machine-like murmur suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can promote the closure of the PDA. Antibiotics or heart transplant are not indicated at this stage, and PGE2 is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in certain specific cases.
